trial_identification.studytitle: Effectiveness of Patient Feedback to Improve Medical Student Consultation Skills
trial_identification.scientifictitle: Use of additional patient satisfaction scores to improve medical student consultation skills compared to verbal feedback as educational intervention

interventions.interventions: Intervention is feedback of Medical Interview Satisfaction Scale (MISS-21), a 21-item validated visit based questionnaire for measuring patient satisfaction, with usual verbal feedback after consultation episodes in patients living with chronic illnesses. The scores are given prior to the last consultation during one semester (generally about 6 consultations in total).

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Tutors give summative assessments using Rating Instrument of Clinical consultation Skills (RICS), a student performance assessment tool

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: Third year medical students in their first clinical year enrolled in Monash University and Deakin University, Australia

sponsorship.primarysponsorname: Eastern Health Clinical School, Monash University and Deakin University

fundingsource.fundingname: FMNHS Learning & Teaching Research Grant Scheme (L&T RGS), Monash University

ethicsAndSummary.summary: This study is designed to test if feedback of patient satisfaction score after consultation sessions improves clinical consultation performance among medical students. We hypothesise that 1) additional feedback of patient satisfaction scores to students improves student performance over usual feedback; and 2) the teaching model increases patient satisfaction scores in student consultation over time.
